qas.question: What is the function of ATP and NADPH molecules?
When is the raw form of glucose formed?
What is stored in the chloroplast?
What is used instead of glucose in sunflowers?

answers.text: for export to the rest of the plant

context: The light energy captured by chlorophyll a is initially in the form of electrons (and later a proton gradient) that's used to make molecules of ATP and NADPH which temporarily <a0_0>store and transport energy<a0_0/>. Their energy is used in the light-independent reactions of the Calvin cycle by the enzyme rubisco to produce molecules of the 3-carbon sugar glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate (G3P). Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate is the <a1_0>first product of photosynthesis<a1_0/> and the raw material from which glucose and almost all other organic molecules of biological origin are synthesized. Some of the glucose is converted to <a2_0>starch<a2_0/> which is stored in the chloroplast. Starch is the characteristic energy store of most land plants and algae, while inulin, a polymer of <a3_0>fructose<a3_0/> is used for the same purpose in the sunflower family Asteraceae. Some of the glucose is converted to sucrose (common table sugar) <a4_0>for export to the rest of the plant<a4_0/>.
